name: User Onboarding to Landing Zone AWS Account.txt - Password Policy
description: This section outlines the password policy requirements for the AWS account, which include having at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, one number, and one non-alphanumeric character. It also provides instructions on how to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for the AWS account by navigating to the user's security credentials section in the AWS console. These measures are implemented to enhance the security of the AWS account by enforcing strong password practices and adding an extra layer of authentication.
use_cases: Enforcing strong password policies for AWS accounts
Enabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for AWS accounts
Enhancing security measures for AWS accounts
Providing step-by-step instructions for enabling MFA

name: User Onboarding to Landing Zone AWS Account.txt - Enable MFA on AWS Account
description: This section explains the process of enabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) on an AWS account for enhanced security. It provides step-by-step instructions on how to set up a virtual MFA device using a compatible mobile application, scan a QR code, enter consecutive codes, and log in to the AWS console with the MFA password. Additionally, it mentions the ability to switch between different AWS accounts within the Landing Zone environment.
use_cases: Enabling MFA on an AWS account for added security
Setting up a virtual MFA device using a mobile application
Switching between multiple AWS accounts within the Landing Zone

name: User Onboarding to Landing Zone AWS Account.txt - Switch to other AWS accounts
description: This section provides instructions on how to switch between different AWS accounts within an organization using AWS Single Sign-On (SSO) and AWS CLI. It includes a table with account names, account IDs, and direct sign-in URLs for various accounts like POC, Production, Data Engineering, Stage, and RedisLabs. The section also explains how to replace the {IAM_username} placeholder in the URLs with your actual IAM username, which is typically your email address before the '@' symbol. Additionally, it provides guidance on using the aws-vault tool to securely store and manage AWS credentials with multi-factor authentication (MFA) for the AWS CLI.
use_cases: Switching between multiple AWS accounts within an organization
Accessing different environments like POC, Production, Stage, etc.
Managing AWS credentials and MFA for AWS CLI
Securely storing AWS access keys using aws-vault
capabilities: Keychain storage for AWS access keys

name: User Onboarding to Landing Zone AWS Account.txt - Using AWS CLI with MFA with aws-vault
description: This section explains how to use the aws-vault tool to securely manage AWS credentials and access multiple AWS accounts with Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). It provides step-by-step instructions for setting up aws-vault, configuring MFA, and accessing different AWS accounts and roles using profiles. The section also covers configuring the Keychain password timeout and provides examples for common use cases like running AWS CLI commands, Terraform, and Python scripts with aws-vault.
use_cases: Securely managing AWS credentials with MFA
Accessing multiple AWS accounts and roles using profiles
Running AWS CLI commands, Terraform, and scripts with aws-vault
Configuring Keychain password timeout for aws-vault
capabilities: Profile-based access to multiple AWS accounts and roles
Integration with AWS CLI, Terraform, and scripting
